ocr_text: UNIVERSITY OF SAN CARLOS SCHOOL OF BUSINESS AND ECONOMICS CS 101, Section A: Introduction to Programming MWF 10 00 AM 11 30 AM Room 301, Engineering Building First Semester, 2026 2027 This course introduces fundamental programming concepts using Python. Students will learn problem solving techniques, algorithm development, and basic programming constructs including variables, data types, control structures, functions, and file handling. COURSE SYLLABUS CONTACT INFORMATION CONTACT INFORMATION Professor: pr. Deanna Brown Office: Room 292, Faculty Building E Mail: george kidd university edu ph Phone: (+63) 915 471 7614 Office Hours: monday, Wednesday Friday, 2 00 PM 3 00 PM WiFi Support Wi Fi Network: UNIVERSITY_WiFi Password: Available at IT Office Business Resource Center Business Resource Center: Learning Commons Hours: Monday Friday 8 00 AM 8 00 PM COURSE DESCRIPTION This course provides a comprehensive introduction to computer programming using Python as the primary language. Students will learn fundamental programming concepts including variables, data types, operators, control structures (conditionals and loops), functions, arrays, and basic file operations. The course emphasizes problem solving skills, algorithm development, and logical thinking. Through hands on laboratory exercises and programming projects, students will gain practical experience in writing, testing, and debugging code. Topics include structured programming principles, modular design, documentation, and software development best practices. Students will also be introduced to integrated development environments (IDEs) and version control systems. The course is designed for students with little or no prior programming experience and serves as foundation for advanced computer science courses. COURSE OBJECTIVES Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: 1. Demonstrate understanding of fundamental programming concepts including variables, data types, operators, and expressions. 2. Apply problem solving techniques to analyze problems, develop algorithms, and implement solutions using Python. 3. Write well structured programs using control structures (sequence, selection, iteration) and functions. 4. Create, manipulate, and process data using arrays, lists, and dictionaries. 5. Design and implement programs that read from and write to files. 6. Debug and test programs to ensure correctness and reliability. 7. Apply good programming practices including proper documentation, meaningful variable names, and code formatting. 8. Collaborate effectively in team programming projects and communicate technical concepts clearly.

ocr_text: UNIVERSITY OF SANTO TOMAS FACULTY OF ARTS AND LETTERS CS 101, Section A: Introduction to Programming MWF 10 00 AM 11 30 AM Room 301, Engineering Building Summer Term, 2024 2027 This course introduces fundamental programming concepts using Python. Students will learn problem solving techniques, algorithm development, and basic Programming constructs including variables, data types, control structures, functions, and file handling. COURSE SYLLABUS CONTACT INFORMATION CONTACT INFORMATION Professor: Dr. Edward Kennedy Office: Room 222, Research Building E Mail: keith ellis university edu ph Phone: (+63) 917 319 7794 Office Hours: tuesday Thursday, 9 00 AM 3 00 PM WiFi Support Wi Fi Network: UNIVERSITY_WiFi Password: Available at IT Office Business Resource Center usiness Resource Center: Library 2nd Floor Hours: Monday Friday 8 00 AM 8 00 PM COURSE DESCRIPTION This course provides a comprehensive introduction to computer programming using Python as the primary language. Students will learn fundamental Programming concepts including variables, data types, operators, control structures (conditionals and loops), functions, arrays, and basic file operations. The course emphasizes problem solving skills, algorithm development, and logical thinking. Through hands on laboratory exercises and Programming projects, students will gain practical experience in writing, testing, and debugging code. Topics include structured programming principles, modular design, documentation, and software development best practices. Students will also be introduced to integrated development environments (IDEs) and version control systems. The course is designed for students with little or no prior programming experience and serves as foundation for advanced computer science courses. COURSE OBJECTIVES Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: 1. Demonstrate understanding of fundamental programming concepts including variables, data types, operators, and expressions. 2. Apply problem solving techniques to analyze problems, develop algorithms, and implement solutions using Python. 3. Write well structured programs using control structures (sequence, selection, iteration) and functions. 4. Create, manipulate, and process data using arrays, lists, and dictionaries. 5. Design and implement programs that read from and write to files. 6. Debug and test programs to ensure correctness and reliability. 7. Apply good programming practices including proper documentation, meaningful variable names, and code formatting. 8. Collaborate effectively in team programming projects and communicate technical concepts clearly.

Students will analyze financial statements and apply financial tools. COURSE SYLLABUS CONTACT INFORMATION CONTACT INFORMATION Professor: br. Susan Simmons Office: Room 369, Research Building E Mail: nathanie sneiton university edu ph Phone: (+63) 902 729 3903 Office Hours: tuesday Thursday, 1 00 PM 11 00 AM WiFi Support Wi Fi Network: POLYTECHNIC_WiFi Password: Available at !T Office Business Resource Center Business Resource Center: Library 2nd Floor Hours: Monday Friday 8 00 AM 8 00 PM OURSE DESCRIPTION This course provides comprehensive study of financial management principies and practices in business organizations. Topics inciude financia! statement analysis, time value of money, capital budgeting techniques, risk and return analysis, cost of capital, capital structure decisions, dividend policy, and working capital management. Students will learn to analyze financial statements, evaluate investment opportunities, determine optimal capital structure, and make strategic financial decisions. The course covers both theoretical frameworks and practical applications using reai word case studies from Philippine and international companies. Emphasis is placed on developing anaiytical skills, critical thinking, and decision making abilities essential for financial managers. Students will use financial calculators, spreadsheet software, and financial analysis tools to solve problems and analyze scenarios. Assess risk and return relationships and apply portfolio theary concepts. 5. Caiculate weighted average cost of capital and understand its role in financial decisions. 6. Analyze capital structure decisions and understand trade offs between debt and equity financing. 7. Evaluate dividend policy alternatives and their impact on shareholder value. 8. Develop strategies for efficient working capital management including cash, inventory, and receivables management.
